title: Cheers: Absinthe is abound this fall
text:
Traditionally, Absinthe is served with cold water poured from a fountain over a sugar cube and mint leaf into a glass. (Photo: Courtesy of Two James Spirits) 
CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE The hot spirit for fall is, once again, absinthe. The green fairy can be seen popping up in bars and restaurants in Detroit this season.
One reason for the piqued interest in the spirit, which was banned in the United States from the early 1900s until 2007, may be because last month Two James Spirits released Absinthe du Nain Rouge. The potent spirit is 120 proof and is available at the distillery’s Corktown tasting room.
“It’s similar to gin in the sense that it starts out with a spirit that you macerate botanicals in, and we have variety of different botanicals that we put in there including wormwood, which is the famous ingredient that makes absinthe absinthe, at least in the traditional sense,” says Two James distiller Joe Lordon. “Then we re-distill the absinthe and from there we take it and give it a coloration so when it comes off the still it’s basically colorless. The green color happens from the second maceration. From there we proof it down to 120 proof.”
Lordon says the Two James tasting room will serve the Absinthe du Nain Rouge the traditional way, with cold water poured from a fountain over a sugar cube and mint leaf into a glass. Two James Spirits is at 2445 Michigan in Detroit.
On Thursday , the Whitney mansion will debut its Absinthe Room as part of the third floor Ghost Bar. The small space is decked out with plush seating, a fireplace and a view of Woodward. The room will also have the appropriate cold water fountains.
The Whitney’s Absinthe Room will be available starting at 6 p.m. Wednesdays-Saturdays. A special Sunday seating 11 a.m.-4 p.m. will be titled Death in the Afternoon in honor of absinthe-lover Ernest Hemingway. The restaurant will serve an absinthe and champagne cocktail and a light brunch.
The Whitney is at 4421 Woodward. Call (313) 832-5700 for reservations.
At Republic Tavern in the Grand Army of the Republic Building, 1942 Grand River, the fall cocktail menu is home to Mr. Green, a liquorice drink made with St. George Absinthe, Sambuca, Drambuie and lemon. The nose-to-tail restaurant recently launched its fall food menu, too, which is stacked with small plates of comfort foods like roasted carrots, corn fritters with avocado mousse, and apples with butternut squash and roquefort cheese.
Deliciously brief 
■ Last week Greektown Casino-Hotel debuted its newest attraction, the Rock Bar and Lounge. Located on the lower level of the casino, the updated space replaces Asteria, which was renovated in 2011. The Rock Bar will serve cocktails named after Detroit streets and guests can enjoy the view of seven 75-inch flat screen televisions and 26 video poker machines.
■ Butter Run Saloon in St. Clair Shores was named by the Bourbon Review as one of the 75 best bourbon bars in the country. It was the only Michigan bar on the list.

Food & beverage events 
Dine Drink Detroit: More than two dozen participating restaurants will offer a special fixed price featuring at least one item of food and one drink for $15. Some of the participating spots are Chartreuse Kitchen & Cocktails, Jolly Pumpkin, Bobcat Bonnie’s, Antietam and Batch Brewing Company. Promotion starts Thursday and runs through Oct. 10. dinedrinkdetroit.com
Oktoberfest at the Howell Opera House: Traditional German dinner from Brunner’s Restaurant, beer and the band Die Dorfmusikanten. 6-11 p.m. Fri. $30. 123 W. Grand River, Howell. (517) 540-0065.
Chappellet Wine at Rattlesnake Club: Wines from the Chappellet Winery in Napa Valley will be paired with five small plates. Advance ticket purchase required. 7 p.m. Fri. $65, plus tax and gratuity. 300 River Place, Detroit. (313) 567-4400.
Barkin’ Good Time Pub Crawl at Fountain Walk, Novi: A benefit for Waggin’ Tails Dog Rescue, this bar crawl hits Mynt, Bar Louie, Tilted Kilt and Lucky Strike. 5-11 p.m. Sat. $30 in advance, $35 at the door. 44175 W. 12 Mile, Novi. (248) 788-7050.
Taste of Southfield at Town Center Atrium: More than 20 restaurants showcase their food, and attendees can vote for their favorite. There also will be cooking demos, raffles and entertainment. 5-8 p.m. Tues. $15-$25. 2000 Town Center Atrium, Southfield. southfieldchamber.com 
Harvest Celebration at Eastern Market: Antietam’s chef Jestin Feggan will team up with Henry Ford College’s Culinary Arts team to create a harvest feast. The Detroit Symphony Orchestra performs. 6:30 p.m. Oct. 8. $250-$400. Shed 5, Eastern Market, Detroit. (313) 833-9300.
Melody Baetens
